ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I thought a lot about historiography in this course than I he previously. There were a lot of historical interpretations presented that I very much disagreed with. Through my independent reading, I feel like I got a solid grasp of many areas of colonial Latin American history.

This class required a lot of independent research for the final paper, as well as active attention to all of the readings outside of class. It taught me how to take lots of notes to make sure I knew what I was talking about during discussion section.

Through various projects and essay writing I was able to improve my writing. I learned a lot about the general history of the geographical region and it helped me broaden my perspective on colonialism. Furthermore, the selected readings were truly influential works.
About pre independence in Latin America
Colonialism is a tool used to propel capitalism
I learned about a region and a history I didnt know much about!

Quite frankly, I had very little knowledge of Latin American history before taking this course. I now feel that I can speak intelligently on the centuries that followed European colonization of Latin America, especially how events on the Iberian Peninsula affected happenings across the Atlantic.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This class was very  disorganized. There seemed to be no communication between the TA and Professor; the professor never knew what we were reading for section, and indeed we did not at all follow the syllabus in section readings. Assignments and due dates were constantly changing; we never actually received a syllabus that even remotely resembled what the course looked like.

It could be hard to know what discussion section would be about beforehand, and it wasn't physically possible to do all of the readings between all my other classes. It would probably be better with fewer readings that get more intensely focused on instead of many readings where we only read 1-2 chapters each.

This course serves as a great introduction to Latin America History and delves deep into the theme of colonialism. It would benefit from better organisation of readings and a stronger, more set syllabus. Nevertheless, this is a great survey course and Professor Schwartz does a great job of making the small lectures engaging.
I think the structure was a bit unorganized
We rarely followed the readings listed on the syllabus, so it was hard to know what content we were learning each day.
I thought the lectures were interesting and discussion sections were engaging. Overall not much to recommend

A major strength of this class was a solid syllabus with books that enriched one's understanding of the content rather than merely repeating the lecture material. A weakness is that a focus on the actions of European powers in Latin America leads to a corresponding lack of focus on native cultures.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would not. The only way I learned much of anything was that I took it upon myself to do most of the readings and undertake an interesting final project. Unless you have a strong particular motive to take the course, I would recommend other preindustrial / Latin American history courses.
Good history credit for someone planning to specialize on Latin America or taking Spanish or Portuguese, probably not necessary otherwise.
Yes, if you're interested in colonial history or Latin America. It also is one of the few history courses offered in this specific region.

Yes, I would recommend this course if you are interested in learning about Spanish colonialism. The course provided an overview of the Spanish conquest of the Americas and colonial structures. The lectures were clear and the readings were interesting.
Yes
Absolutely!
I would recommend this to someone with little background knowledge of Latin American history who is fine with a traditional lecture-style course.
